references: In this section, we elaborate the architectures and training algorithms of SlimFL. The network under study consists of
devices. Following the federated averaging algorithm
-th device trains a local SNN model
using its local dataset, and communicates with a parameter server storing a global model. The SNN
is divided into the LH segment
x model is the stack of both segments, i.e.,
In the uplink, the device uploads the SC-encoded local model
to the server. After reception, according to (
, the server can successively decode using SD and obtain: (i) the
x model if the channel fading gain satisfies
; and (iii) otherwise it obtains no model. In the downlink, SC and SD are also applied, so the global model is obtained at each device according to the aforementioned conditions.
In between the uplink and downlink, the device locally trains its SNN. Existing SNN architectures and training algorithms are intended for standalone learning
. Towards improving the scalability for federated learning, we propose a lighter model architecture and training algorithm as detailed next.
The state-of-the-art SNN architecture is the US-MobileNet proposed in

standard neural network architecture with a universal batch normalization (BN) layer, US-MobileNet is equipped with multiple separate BN layers to cope with all slimmable model configurations. While effective in standalone learning, in SlimFL with wireless connectivity, not all slimmable model segments are exchanged due to insufficient communication throughput, while the exchanged model segements are aggregated across devices, diluting the effectiveness of BN. In our experiments we even observed training convergence failures due to BN. Furthermore, managing multiple BN layers not only consumes additional memory costs, but also entails high computing computing overhead. For these reasons, we remove BN layers, and consider a lighter version of US-MobileNet, named
, with the specifics provided in Tab.
. Compared to US-MobileNet with more than 100M FLOPS, UL-MobileNet costs only 2.76M FLOPS.
The sandwich rule and the inplace distillation algorithm are two notable techniques for training an SNN

x model becomes a teacher guiding its sub-width models via knowledge distillation. By nature, it gives more benefits under a larger SNN (i.e., a better teacher) having more sub-width configurations (i.e., more students). This is unfit for our case with the UL-MobileNet having only two width configurations, the

x models. Furthermore, distillation requires to sequentially train the teacher and student models, incurring additional memory and computing costs. Alternatively, inspired a technique for a depth-controllable neural network
x model are weighted averaged, yielding the following weight update rule:

is a learning rate. With such lighter training overhead, in our SlimFL experiments, superposition training achieved even slightly higher accuracy than that with the sandwich rule and inplace distillation, as further discussed in Appendix
. The overall SlimFL operations are summarized in Algorithm 1.

references: To show the effectiveness and feasibility of SlimFL, in this section we present the performance of SLimFL exploiting SC and SD compared to its Vanilla FL counterpart without SC nor SD, in terms of accuracy, communication efficiency, and energy efficiency, as well as their robustness to various channel conditions and non-IID data distributions.

Our goal is enabling each device to obtain both large and small models so as to cope with its large and small energy levels in future. To this end, by leveraging SNNs with SC and SD, SlimFL simultaneously exchanges and trains
x models by consuming the per-device bandwidth
. This is compared with a Vanilla FL baseline,
. Due to the lack of width-adjustable SNNs, each device in Vanilla FL-
, respectively. Without SC nor SD, the device exchanges both
x models separately. In brief, Vanilla FL-
x is tantamount to simultaneously running the two federated averaging operations separately for
x models by doubling the bandwidth, transmission power, and computing resources. For clarity, we report the performance of Vanilla FL-
x individually if available (i.e., accuracy, received bits), and otherwise we report only Vanilla FL-
We consider a classification task by default with the Fashion MNIST dataset. Following the method proposed in
, the non-IIDness of the dataset distribution across devices is controlled by the Dirichlet distribution with its concentration parameter
is more non-IID distributed (i.e., more imbalanced numbers of samples over labels across devices), as visualized in Fig.
. For a limited set of simulations, the MNIST dataset is also studied, which is deferred to Appendix

. A single round of uplink and downlink communications is followed by every single local training epoch. The communication channels over different devices are orthogonal in both uplink and downlink. The small-scale fading gain
for each channel realization follows an exponential distribution
. Other communication and training hyperparameters as well as the SNN model architecture are summarized in Tab.
. For the given transmission power levels and channel environments, the decoding success probabilities in the uplink and downlink are provided in Tab.
show that both SlimFL and Vanilla FL achieve high accuracy in good channel conditions. However as the channel condition deteriorates from good to poor channels, Fig.
illustrate that the maximum accuracy of Vanilla FL-1.0x at
. Meanwhile, the accuracy of Slim-FL-1.0x keeps the same maximum accuracy
under both good and poor channels. What is more, at
% higher top-1 accuracy than Vanilla FL-1.0x that consumes more communication and computing costs. Furthermore, the std of Vanilla FL-1.0x’s top-1 accuracy increases by up to
% as channel condition deteriorates, whereas that of SlimFL increases by only up to
%. These results advocate the robustness of SlimFL against poor channels, as well as its robustness to non-IID data distributions (i.e., low
) and communication efficiency, as elaborated next.
, SlimFL-0.5x shows a stable convergence under the conditions of
. Vanilla FL-0.5x and Vanilla FL-1.0x exhibit the std of 8.3 and 9.2, in poor communication condition and with the non-IID dataset (
). On the contrary, both SlimFL-0.5x and SlimFL-1.0x exhibit the std of 2.4 and 2.9 at top-1 accuracy respectively. This tendency holds even when
. SlimFL-1.0x and SlimFL-0.5x exhibit lower variation than Vanilla FL-1.0x and Vanilla FL-0.5x. This underscores the robustness of SlimFL to non-IID data distributions in poor channels.

The total amount of transmitted bits between 10 devices and server in ideal channel conditions (i.e., always successful decoding) are 205.8MBytes for SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.0x, and 102.9MBytes for Vanilla FL-0.5x.
Tab.
shows that SlimFL achieves up to

% less dropped bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x, thanks to the use of SC and SD. The reduced dropped bits of SlimFL can be found by the successfully decoded bits of 0.5x models that cannot be simultaneously received under Vanilla FL-1.0x. Note that SlimFL decodes less 1.0x model bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x, as a part of transmission power of SlimFL is allocated to 0.5x models. In return, SlimFL not only receives 1.0x models but also 0.5x models simultaneously. The additionally received 0.5x models correspond to the LH parts of the 1.0x models, which therefore improve the accuracy and convergence speed of both 0.5x and 1.0x models. SlimFL enjoys the aforementioned benefits while consuming only the half of the transmission power and bandwidth compared to Vanilla FL-1.5x, as illustrated in Tab.
Thus far we have measured the performance of SlimFL after training with a fixed

epochs. Here, we measure the energy expenditure until convergence, where the training convergence is defined by the moment when the standard deviation (std) of test accuracy is below a target threshold and the minimum test accuracy becomes higher than the average test accuracy in
consecutive rounds (see the details in Appendix
). Given the communication and computing energy costs per round in Tab.
compares the total energy costs of SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.5x until convergence. The results show that on average, SlimFL achieves
x less total computing cost with

x lower total communication cost until convergence. Such higher energy efficiency comes from the faster convergence of SlimFL even under non-IID distributions and/or poor channel conditions thanks to SC and SD.

The additionally received 0.5x models correspond to the LH parts of the 1.0x models, which therefore improve the accuracy and convergence speed of both 0.5x and 1.0x models. Thus far we have measured the performance of SlimFL after training with a fixed

epochs. Here, we measure the energy expenditure until convergence, where the training convergence is defined by the moment when the standard deviation (std) of test accuracy is below a target threshold and the minimum test accuracy becomes higher than the average test accuracy in
consecutive rounds (see the details in Appendix
). Given the communication and computing energy costs per round in Tab.
compares the total energy costs of SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.5x until convergence. The results show that on average, SlimFL achieves
x less total computing cost with

x lower total communication cost until convergence. Such higher energy efficiency comes from the faster convergence of SlimFL even under non-IID distributions and/or poor channel conditions thanks to SC and SD.

references: To show the effectiveness and feasibility of SlimFL, in this section we present the performance of SLimFL exploiting SC and SD compared to its Vanilla FL counterpart without SC nor SD, in terms of accuracy, communication efficiency, and energy efficiency, as well as their robustness to various channel conditions and non-IID data distributions.

Our goal is enabling each device to obtain both large and small models so as to cope with its large and small energy levels in future. To this end, by leveraging SNNs with SC and SD, SlimFL simultaneously exchanges and trains

The total amount of transmitted bits between 10 devices and server in ideal channel conditions (i.e., always successful decoding) are 205.8MBytes for SlimFL and Vanilla FL-1.0x, and 102.9MBytes for Vanilla FL-0.5x.
Tab.
shows that SlimFL achieves up to

% less dropped bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x, thanks to the use of SC and SD. The reduced dropped bits of SlimFL can be found by the successfully decoded bits of 0.5x models that cannot be simultaneously received under Vanilla FL-1.0x. Note that SlimFL decodes less 1.0x model bits than Vanilla FL-1.0x, as a part of transmission power of SlimFL is allocated to 0.5x models. In return, SlimFL not only receives 1.0x models but also 0.5x models simultaneously. The additionally received 0.5x models correspond to the LH parts of the 1.0x models, which therefore improve the accuracy and convergence speed of both 0.5x and 1.0x models. SlimFL enjoys the aforementioned benefits while consuming only the half of the transmission power and bandwidth compared to Vanilla FL-1.5x, as illustrated in Tab.
